In the end I decided to stick to one definition instead of alternating between two.

kogla was easier to remember and more intuitive then kospu.
I simply remembered one form better.
I used them randomly
It was actually random most of the time. However, I did use 'kospu' and nefri as a combination, and kogla nezno more.
nefri was for 2 objects and blue colour nezno was for 2 objects but grey colour. while kospu was for one object.
I did not pick up any pattern for which forms were used together so I often selected kogla/kospu and nezno/nefri randomly
Basic idea from the training then trail and error in the tests.

It was easier to learn at first only one of each pair, therefore I chose Kogla and Nefri. These I could associate with words I already know, this helps them stick and makes them easier to remember by linking them with specific words. Once these were solidified in my mind I then tried remembering the other 2 using the same method.
picked one combination and stuck with it

After determining the object as either mokte or jalpa, I would follow with the word kospu if singular, or kogla if plural should the colour be purple. If white I would not use the a k word. If there was one object i would end the description with nezno, if two I would use nefri. There was much error due to confusion memorizing in the short space of time though.
By recollecting what Glerma had used during the tutorial session.
I learned the 6 words and what they meant and then used the 2 pairs of synonyms equally. That is, I tried to use every descriptive word the same amount.
Nefri and nezden were used for number of objects and kogla and kospu were for colour, but I didn't decipher when to use each form together.

I think that 'kogla' and 'kospu' are synonyms, and 'nezno' and 'nefri' are synonyms, so I initially tried to use them all with the same frequency. But 'kogla' and 'nefri' were more memorable and I ended up preferring them - especially 'kogla nefri' as a single phrase.
blue was kogla/kospu and double was nefri/nezno both used with each other respectively.
Basically I choose the ones I could easily remember.
mokte was the one lying on the ground and open from top whereas for Jelpa it was thought to be in the air with top close
It was mostly due to the first time I heard each form used for the colour or the number of objects, it created an association that this is the primary terminology.
I alternated between 'kogla' and 'kospu' in no particular order, since I deduced they meant the same thing.

nefri and kogla were more memorable, so I used them more frequently. occasionally the same image was shown several times in quick succession, so i used nezno instead. Kospu was less memorable to me during the training, so I did not use it.
I decided based on the frequency of the use of colour ,number combinations
I used kogla to describe whether the objects were coloured blue or not
blue - kospu or kogla. grey - nefri or neon
It was easier to remember the language when I put the object first
I did it according to English language trad structure; number, colour object.
I tried to make the world order random, as I couldn't really see a pattern in Glerma's use.
I'm not really sure, I feel like it was quite spontaneous; whatever feature I recognised first, or which word I remembered first. Maybe the name of the object was what came first most often.
I determined that there was no difference in the pictures for the different word order so therefore I just used whichever combination that came to mind - usually I started with jelpa or mokte
It sounded better in my head to say 'nefri kogla' because I think its means two blue whatever?
constantly used 'nefri' 'kogla' then 'mokte/jelpa' in this order.
I used what seemed like the most common word order used by Glerma - noun, adjective, number.
object, colour, number of objects
I normally used kogla and jefri after the object names (mokte and jelpa), but sometimes i used them before out of boredom
Trying to alternate with the word order changes (so 50% of each)
The order that allowed me to remember the words most accurately because it flowed best.
In 2-word descriptions always had the nefri at the end and kolga at the begining. In 3-word descriptions, for jelpra had kolga at the beginning and nefri at the end. Mokte was always the last word.
Object always comes first, then color and positioning. I assumed they could be rearranged in any order as they can be in other languages.
Started with the shapes name. Then The color if its blue. Lastly, the number which is nefri (meaning two).

The order in which I learned the words felt the most natural. I was confused why she kept switching things around and I didn't want that to hinder myself from creating sentences later on.

what was easier to remember
it was random, just the first of the kogla or nefri to come to my head

number, colour, object

if it was "jelpa" then the word order was important

What ever order sounded best in my head, and was easiest to remember

In the order that I recognised the features

always noun first, and nefri last
